Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial of Acridine Orange Therapy Versus Conventional Wide-Margin Resection in Soft Tissue Sarcoma

Intervention.evidence: randomised to receive either acridine orange therapy (n=51) or conventional wide-margin resection (n=119)

Objective.evidence: This study evaluates a less radical surgical approach using adjunctive acridine orange therapy.

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was overall survival at 10 years.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was conducted using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Blinding.evidence: Outcome assessors were blinded to group allocation.

Number_Randomised.evidence: randomised to receive either acridine orange therapy (n=51) or conventional wide-margin resection (n=119)

Result_Outcome.evidence: The 10-year overall survival rates were 68% for the acridine orange group and 63% for the conventional group.

Harms.evidence: No significant adverse events were reported in either group.
